questions.text: Rakesh comes to OPD with diplopia. Which of the following is least likely to be seen in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Latent squint Latent squint does not always present with diplopia . Intermittent diplopia (only under fatigue temporarily) Heterophoria (Latent squint) is a condition in which the tendency of the eyes to deviate is kept latent by fusion . When the influence of fusion is removed, the visual axis of one eye deviates away. Types: Esophoria-convergent Exophoria-divergent Hyperphoria-deviation upwards Hypophoria-deviation downwards Cyclophoria-rotation around AP axis Symptoms: Usually an asymptomatic-compensated In cases where there are symptoms decompensated type Headache Eye ache Photophobia Intermittent diplopia (only under fatigue temporarily)

Random:

Explanation for other options: - Option: A. Manifest squint - Manifest or latent: manifest squint is present when the eyes are open and being used; whereas in latent squint the eye turns only when it is covered or shut. Option: B . Paralytic squint - Paralytic strabismus etiology Neurogenic lesions Congenital hypoplasia or absence of nucleus third and sixth cranial nerve palsies. Inflammatory lesions: encephalitis,meningitis, neurosyphilis, peripheral neuritis (viral), infectious lesions of cavernous sinus and orbit. Neoplastic lesions. Vascular lesions:HTN, DM and atherosclerosis. haemorrhage, thrombosis, embolism, aneurysms or vascular occlusions. Option: D. Restrictive squint - Restrictive strabismus is a type of ocular misalignment with limitation of motility caused by intrinsic or extrinsic mechanical forces. The clinical spectrum of either purely or partially restrictive strabismus is very broad.

Extraedge:

DIFFERENCE BW PARALYTIC AND RESTRICTIVE SQUINT Clinical Features Paralytic Squint Restrictive Squint Deviation in primary position Present and is proportional to the degree of underaction of the affected muscle May be present, absent or paradoxical; is generally disproportionately mild compared to the degree of underaction and can even be paradoxical, e.g. an exotropia in Duane retraction syndrome with a deficiency of abduction Forced duction test or ability to move the eye mechanically using a forceps to hold the anaesthetized eye at the limbus Negative, i.e. the eye can be easily moved in the direction of restricted movement Positive, i.e. the eye cannot be mechanically moved in the direction of restricted movement Active force generation test Negative or weak force generation The positive or normal force generated by the muscle

questions.text: A mother brings her 5-year-old baby boy to your clinic complaining that his eyes deviate when he studies or plays with his puzzle-solving game. On gross examination, his eyes look straight at you. What is the next step for the management of the child?

options.label: A
options.text: Checking for visual acuity & refraction under atropine

questions.correct_answer: A. Checking for visual acuity & refraction under atropine
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Checking for visual acuity & refraction under atropine Deviation of a child's eyes on & off suggests the presence of heterophoria . The first step to managing such a case is checking for visual acuity & refraction with cycloplegic & checking for fundus . The most common cause of squint in a child is uncorrected refractive error.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: B. Cover uncover test: The most simple is the cover test . When a distant object isregarded, and both eyes are uncovered, there is no deviation. One eye is then covered so that the eyes dissociate and the latent deviation appears . When the screen is removed, this eye moves at once to regain the position of binocular fixation . The other eye reacts similarly, with the deviation in both being the same. Option: C. Alternate cover test: The alternate cover test is the most dissociative cover test and measures the total deviation, which includes the tropia plus the phoria . For this test, the examiner occludes one eye and then the other, switching the occluder back and forth between eyes. Option: D. Maddox rod test: Maddox rod testing for ocular misalignment . By Convention, the Maddox rod is always placed over the right eye and the patient is asked to fixate on a bright white light either at a distance or A binocular patient’s right eye sees a red line, while the uncovered left eye sees the white light.

Extraedge:

INTERPRETATIONS OF COVER TEST

questions.text: A child presents to you with a complaint of deviation of the right eye as noticed & told by his parents. On gross examination, the eyes seem straight. The following test is used to screen for the squint in your clinic.
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Bruckner’S Test The first screening test for squint in your clinic using a direct ophthalmoscope is Bruckner's test . Both eyes are simultaneously seen using a direct ophthalmoscope . The deviated eye is brighter & lighter than the normal eye. Thus this test screens for squint but doesn’t measure the amount of squint . The prism bar cover test measures the amount of squint . The Brückner test is a low-cost, simple and quick method to detect anisometropia and strabismus among children . Being an objective test it can be used among preverbal children and patients uncooperative for alternate cover testing. Strabismus: A "positive" Brückner test indicative of strabismus is characterized by: Asymmetry of the red reflex. Unequal pupil sizes. Displacement of the central light reflex. The child in this photo has a right Esotropia/ Exotropia. The Brückner Test with the direct ophthalmoscope is a simple and useful examination to diagnose ametropia and abnormalities of the eye at an early stage to prevent irreversible amblyopia

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: B. Prism bar cover test measures the amount of squint Option: C . Pupillary reaction doesn’t screen squint but is helpful for looking for a decrease in vision.

Extraedge:

Prism bar test This is the most commonly used method in routine clinical practice. T he Angle of deviation can be measured with the prism cover test using prisms of different strengths (either loose prisms or mounted prism bars) in front of one eye with the apex pointing towards the deviation and repeating the test till the corrective movement of the eye is neutralized. The strength of the prism which is needed for neutralization gives the objective angle of deviation.

questions.text: Which of the following tests measures heterophorias at a near distance?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Maddox’s wing test This measures the heterophoria for near distance (33cm) subjectively. It is based on the principle of dissociation of fusion by dissimilar objects. The right eye sees a white vertical arrow & red horizontal arrow and the left eye sees a vertical & horizontal line of numbers. Thus the patient tells which number is the red & white arrow pointing giving the degree of deviation. Cyclophorias can also be measured using the Maddox wing test.

Highyeild:

The deviation in near vision is conveniently tested by the Maddox wing test, in which the patient looks through the two-slit holes in the eyepieces of the instrument. The Maddox Wing measures the size of heterophorias (latent deviations) and small heterotropias (manifest deviations) near when normal retinal correspondence (NRC) is present. It is especially helpful when patients present with symptoms of diplopia (double vision) with no apparent cause.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A . Bruckner’s Test: The Brückner test is a low-cost, simple and quick method to detect anisometropia and strabismus among children . Being an objective test it can be used among preverbal children and patients uncooperative for alternate cover testing. Option: B . Maddox Rod Test: The Maddox rod test can be used to subjectively detect and measure latent, manifest, horizontal or vertical strabismus for near and distance . The test is based on the principle of diplopic projection.

Extraedge:

The double Maddox rod test can also be used to assess torsion and measure cyclotropias . It is a subjective test which uses two M addox rods, one before each eye. It is used to determine cyclodeviation or torsion . This test can be done in all the positions of gazes for comparison.

questions.text: What is the basis for using the Maddox rod test for testing heterophorias?

options.label: A
options.text: Breakage of fusion by creating dissimilar images

options.label: B
options.text: Breakage of fusion by not allowing simultaneous perception

questions.correct_answer: A. Breakage of fusion by creating dissimilar images
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Breakage of fusion by creating dissimilar images A latent squint is kept latent because of fusion. On breakage of this fusion, the squint manifests. This can be done by either creating dissimilar images or by not allowing simultaneous perception to develop . Since there is no simultaneous perception there will be no fusion so the latent squint will manifest. Maddox rod test creates dissimilar images in front of both eyes . One eye sees the point source of light & the other sees the streak of light. Thus these dissimilar images don’t allow fusion & the latent squint manifests.

Highyeild:

MADDOX ROD TEST PRINCIPLE : Diplopic projection : Breakage of fusion by creating dissimilar images PROCEDURE : When the Maddox rod is placed vertically over the right eye, the patient should see a horizontal red line and a white light. When the Maddox rod is placed horizontally over the right eye, the patient should see a vertical red line and a white light. If the eyes are aligned, the red line will go through the white light. INTERPRETATIONS A) Esodeviation, B) Exodeviation, C) Hypo-deviation, D) Hyper-deviation, E) No deviation

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: B .Breakage of fusion by not allowing simultaneous perception - this is not the correct option - because it is by creating dissimilar images So Options C and D are also incorrect

questions.text: A patient comes to your clinic complaining of intermittent deviation of his left eye while he is stressed at the office. There is a past history of the same eye deviation a few days back when the patient had a fever. On screening for squint, the left eye has exophoria. How will you keep the prism bar cover test to measure the squint?

options.label: A
options.text: Prism with the base out over the left eye & cover over the right eye

options.label: B
options.text: Prism with the base in over the left eye & cover over the right eye

options.label: C
options.text: Prism with the base in over the right eye & cover over the left eye

options.label: D
options.text: Prism with the base out over the right eye & cover over the left eye

questions.correct_answer: B. Prism with the base in over the left eye & cover over the right eye
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Prism with the base in over the left eye & cover over the right eye PBCT objectively measures both heterophoria & heterotopias. This can detect squint both at a distance & near . The prisms of increasing strength with the apex towards the direction of deviation are kept over the squinting eye. The occluder is placed over the other eye. The prisms are increased in strength till the movement of the squinting eye is neutralised. So in the case of exophoria prisms with apex out & base in are kept in front of the left eye.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A. Prism with the base out over the left eye & cover over the right eye - no, this is not correct because the prisms of increasing strength with the apex towards the direction of deviation are kept over the squinting eye. Option: C. Prism with base in over right eye & cover over left eye- no because the prisms of increasing strength with the apex towards the direction of deviation are kept over the squinting eye Option: D. Prism with the base out over the right eye & cover over the left eye- no, because the apex towards the direction of deviation is kept over the squinting eye

questions.text: What is the correct order of strategies for the management of heterophoria patients? A) Refractive correction B) Orthoptic exercise C) Prisms D) Surgery Select the correct answer from the given below ciode:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

A, B, C, D For the management of squint patients, the first & foremost step is to modestly check for refractive error with cycloplegia & correcting the same. Statement A - Correcting the refractive error corrects the squint in most of the patients. Statement B - Then the patient is trained with orthoptic exercises to strengthen the fusional reserves so that bifoveal single vision can be maintained without much effort. Statement C - Prisms are used to permanently correct the heterophoria. Prisms are better suited for vertical squints than horizontal ones. Statement D - Surgeries are the last resort when all other modalities fail. Surgery is decided according to the muscle concerned. If symptoms are apparent after any error of refraction has been corrected with spectacles , rational treatment of eso- or exophoria consists in exercising the weak muscles against prisms (with the base of the prism in the direction of deviation) or by the use of the synoptophore. In all cases in which the deviation is large and unaffected by such treatment, the operation may be considered, with one or other muscle being recessed or resected.

Extraedge:

Outline of Clinical and Investigative Evaluation of a Patient with Strabismus Case history Chief complaint Onset and duration Previous treatment Family history Diagnostic tests Visual acuity and monocular fixation pattern Cycloplegic refraction and fundus examination Look for any change in head posture and test ocular movements Determine details of deviation Tests for binocularity Forced duction test (if movements are restricted) Management plan Estimate prognosis Patient/parent counselling
